yeasts.name: Classic English Ale
yeasts.description:
This yeast is best used in Extra Special Bitters and Pale Ales as well as other British styles.
Vacuum packed in foil for freshness.
Each 12 g sachet is suitable for up to 23 litres of wort.
Best fermented between 18-22 C for medium attenuation, this will leave some body in the finished product.
Attenuation 66-74%
Ingredients: Yeast, emulsifier (E491).

mashFermentables.name: Pale Ale Malt
mashFermentables.notes:
Flagon Variety. 
Top quality Norfolk-grown 2-row winter malting barley is widely recognised as the best raw material for traditional ale malt. Low protein barleys are sourced from local farmers who are in partnership with Crisp Malting Group through the ABC Grower Group and are qualified as the very best malting barley growers. During malting, high cast moistures and a balance of germination time and temperature guarantee an even, well modified malt which is ideally suited to ale brewing. The characteristic higher colour and balanced sweet, malty flavour results in this malt being one of the most popular and distinctive malt styles. Crisp Malting Group Best Ale Malt is suited to infusion mashing and top fermentation which typifies traditional ale brewing, but is also very well suited for ale brewing using more modern techniques.

mashFermentables.usedIn: Up to 10 of grist, good in stouts.
mashFermentables.name: Flaked Barley

otherFermentables.notes:
Finest quality spray dried malt extract light.
To make a 1 litre yeast starter at 1.040 add 113 grams
Each 1 kg equals 1.035 starting gravity in 10 litres.
3.27 kg in 23 litres gives a starting gravity of 1.050, making an end product of approximately 5%
otherFermentables.name: Spray Dried Malt Extract - Light

hops.name: Fuggles
hops.notes: Traditionally used with Golding. The delicate, minty, grassy, slightly floral aroma produces a clean,refreshing, full-bodied flavour present in many traditional ales. Before the advent of dual purpose and high alpha hops Fuggles were used as the main copper hop and were often complimented by an addition of Golding to give a rounded, full-bodied flavour for which English Ales became famous.
